Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Modeling movement and survival of intercontinental songbird migrants crossing the Gulf of Mexico
Award.AbstractNarration: Approximately two-thirds of all songbird species that breed in eastern North America migrate to tropical areas for the winter, requiring most species to cross the Gulf of Mexico. Flights across the gulf are considered hazardous and may result in mass mortality. Atmospheric conditions over water, as well as characteristics of the birds themselves (e.g., age, physical condition), are likely important predictors of birds' migratory routes and survival. However, most knowledge about when, where and how small birds cross large water bodies and their survival remains speculative, because until now researchers have been unable to track individuals between the start and end points of over water flights. Anticipated changes in atmospheric structure and dynamics caused by climate change urgently require an understanding of how migrating birds interact with the atmosphere. This knowledge will provide insight to potential consequences of climate change on migratory songbirds, many of which are experiencing population declines. Knowledge of animal-atmosphere relationships is timely as wind energy development accelerates and coastal habitat alteration along migratory flyways continues. The interdisciplinary research team will combine modern radio telemetry and favorable geography to document migratory flights of songbirds across the gulf. By integrating field data, atmospheric data and computational simulations and analyses, the team will provide the first estimate of songbird survival during migration across open water. They also will study factors shaping birds' migratory routes and timing. The team will promote learning, excitement and appreciation for science, and animal migration in particular, to non-scientists through educational materials (e.g., animated migration trajectories in Google EarthÂ©). The team will disseminate findings to scientists, reserve managers and the general public via presentations, publications, a bilingual project website, and popular media. American and Latino undergraduate and graduate students and post-doctoral researchers will participate in each phase of research to acquire learning and skill-building opportunities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
For centuries scientists and the general public have been fascinated by the ability of birds to quickly migrate hundreds, if not thousands of miles. In eastern North America the Gulf of Mexico is a 1000km geographic feature that the majority of migratory birds must negotiate. We worked along the northern Gulf Coast and in the Yucatan of Mexico to investigate how birds are able to cross the Gulf, and to determine how risky crossing the Gulf is for birds. We used automated radio telemetry to monitor the departure of birds from the northern Gulf Coast, primarily near Fort Morgan Peninsula, AL, and the arrival of these birds along the northern tip of the Yucatan Peninsula in Mexico. This approach allowed us to determine what factors influenced birds to attempt crossing the Gulf, whether or not they successfully crossed the Gulf, and how fast they could make the 1000km trip.

 

Our research has shown that different species have different approaches to crossing the Gulf. For example, Swainson’s Thrushes are able to fly over the Gulf if they are fat enough and wind conditions are favorable, and on average can cross the Gulf in 22 hours.  In contrast, the small Ruby-throated Hummingbird does not attempt to cross, but rather goes around the Gulf. In general, for all birds except hummingbirds, there are two factors that determine first whether or not an individual attempts to cross the Gulf of Mexico, and second whether they are successful crossing the Gulf.  These factors are wind and how fat an individual is. Fat is the energy source birds use to migrate; given the long journey in terms of distance, time, and opportunity to encounter variable conditions, it follows that individuals with more fat are more likely to survive the crossing. Wind is a factor that can make the crossing easier (tail winds) or conversely make the crossing a very dangerous activity.

 

Previous research has found that crossing the Gulf of Mexico can be risky. One piece of evidence is the presence of landbirds in the stomach of sharks. Presumably these birds are dying of exhaustion as they fly and the sharks are eating the floating corpses. While crossing the Gulf is expected to be dangerous, we found that under ideal conditions crossing the Gulf poses little risk to the individual. However, under less than ideal conditions the crossing might be one of the riskiest events of an individual’s life. Surviving the crossing is slim if birds attempt to cross under strong headwinds, regardless of their body condition. For lean birds, survival remains low even under favorable wind conditions. As would be expected, given this risk, only six of the 76 lean birds in our study attempted to cross the Gulf, and only one of them was subsequently detected in the Yucatan Peninsula. However, that individual spent nine days in Alabama, likely gaining fat, before it departed across the Gulf.  

 

This study improves our understanding of the behavior of migrating birds, but also provides important information that can be used to help conserve migratory species. The majority of migratory species are experiencing population declines. Our research highlights that wind and fat are important factors in predicting if a birds can successfully negotiate the Gulf. We have no control over wind, but conservationist and managers can impact fat. By creating high-quality habitat birds can quickly accumulate the fat they need to cross the Gulf. Unfortunately much of the land along the Gulf coast is being developed, and this study highlights the need to protect some habitats in order to give birds the opportunity to “fatten up”. The flipside of this that we also need to promote the conservation of habitat in the Yucatan. The Yucatan (i.e. Rivera Maya) is a popular tourist area and the increase in tourism has resulted in the loss of habitat. Birds that burn all their fat crossing the Gulf need habitat on the southern coast to refuel. The data collected via this research can provide recommendations on where to conserve habitat in the Yucatan.

 

In summary, migratory birds are capable of amazing movements across large expanses of open water very quickly, but only by taking advantage of tail winds and fat reserves. We have and continue to work with organization in both the US and Mexico to educate people about the plight migratory birds and what may be done to facilitate the amazing migration of birds.
